A primer on control methods

20 Dec 2015

I’ve been rambling on about control algorithms and errors and sensing and estimates, but that doesn’t make it clearer as to how does it actually work ! Here’s a quick primer, which I will probably expand on in a following post.

Indirection

The essential idea here is that there is a bridge between reality and what the drone (or whatever robot or device you are trying to control) actually perceives. Nevertheless we need a way to associate the outside world to how the quad sees itself.

The first consideration is : how do we define the state the drone is in ? We need a consistent, reproducible way to express where the drone is and how it is behaving. For that we use state variables : the minimal set of information you need to accurately pinpoint the behavior of what you are observing or controlling. In our context this will consist of a certain number of parameters : acceleration, speed, position, attitude. This set of 12 variables (3 for each) is sufficient to accurately depict the drone’s state.

Now to the fun part : how do these variables relate to outside world and how do we have control over them ? As you recall me mentioning, the outside world is messy and full of errors : we can’t just assign these variables to the values measured by our sensors. Instead, a layer of abstraction is added between the two worlds : the state estimate is updated through a kind of blackbox that will process the data coming in so it makes sense to the estimate (just like we did for MSF), but it is also updated by the control mechanism. The tricky part is, the control mechanism itself relies on the previous state estimate : the loop is looped, and we get something that looks a bit like the following figure.

Actual control

A control algorithm can be defined in a simple way : it is a mathematical function which when given an input (a state estimate) and a command (a desired state) will spit out the new state estimate that will lead to our command. We can then apply this computed state to our controlled object to obtain the desired effect : for example by applying a certain thrust value to certain motor to move in the commanded direction.
